name: Oxygen Delivery
question1: Describe and draw the Oxygen cascade.  What is the pasteur point? What is the alveolar gas equation.
contents:
Oxygen cascade:

  • Air => 21.3kPa
  • PO2 = FIO2 . Patm. (eg .21 x 101kPa)
  • PO2 of air at sea level is 21.3kPa
  • Trachea => 19.8kPa
  • Humidification = PO2 = FiO2 (Patm - SVP)
  • Humidification = PiO2 needs to be adjusted to subtract water vapour partial pressure at body temperature = 0.21 x (100kPa - 6.3kPa) = 19.8kPa at 1atm

Drop to 15kPa (Mixing with dead space gases) - Ventilated not perfused.

  • Alveolus => 13.8 kPa
  • Ventilation = PO2 = FiO2 (Patm - SVP) - PaCO2 / RQ. ==> AGE. (Alveolar PCO2 is normally between 4.7-6.0kPa)
  • RQ:
  • Carbohydrate = 1.0
  • Protein = 0.8
  • Fat = 0.7

A-a gradient (drop by 2kPa) from (PAO2 = 15kPa, and PaO2 = 13.3kPa)

  • Capillary => 6-7kPa
  • Diffusion = Diffusion barrier negligible for O2. ()
  • Artery =>
  • Shunt. = A-a gradient usually < 2kPa
  • Mitochondria => Greatest drop in PO2 is between the artery (13.3kPa) and mitochondria (1-5kPa)
  • Low PO2 of around 1.5kPa is usual
  • The Pasteur point is the oxygen concentration below which oxidative phosphorylation cannot occur in the mitochondria. It is considered to be around 1mmHg (0.13kPa)
  • Veins = = Normal PvO2 =

Important points:

  • Alveoli are 0.3mm in diameter, the blood gas barrier is 0.3µm thick

Transport:

Alveolar minute ventilation (5.25L/min) roughly equals pulmonary blood flow (5L/min)

RBCs transverse the alveolar capillary in 0.75 secs

Biggest PaO2 - PvO2 difference is in the heart

70-80% of oxygen extracted at rest; 90% during exercise
question2: Define dead space as applied to the respiratory system.
contents2:
Physiological dead space - can be split into two :

  • (1) Anatomical dead space
  • (2) Alveolar dead space


Anatomical dead space :

  • The conducting airways - not involved in gas exchange
  • airway generations 1–16: trachea, bronchi, bronchioles and terminal bronchioles)
  • Includes the mouth, nose and pharynx
  • 2ml/kg (roughly 120 mls for a 60kg)
  • Anatomical dead space INCREASED by: sitting up, neck extension and jaw protrusion, increasing age, increasing lung volume
  • Anatomical dead space DECREASED by: GA, hypoventilation, intubation, tracheostomy.


Alveolar dead space:

  • Constitutes alveoli that are ventilated but not perfused and, therefore, no gas exchange occurs
  • Can be significantly affected by physiological and pathological processes
question3: How is dead space type (1) measured?
contents3:
Fowlers method


Y axis - N2 concentration (expired %)

X axis - Lung Volume L


Note *** final point on x axis on the RHS is the RV.

  • Phase 1 = only oxygen as from dead space
  • Phase 2 = linear rise in nitrogen = mixture of large airway dead space gas + alveolar gas. (Line halfway through = anatomical dead space)
  • Phase 3 = plateau in nitrogen, slope depends on uniform distribution of gas in alveoli
  • Phase 4 = airway closure begins in basal lung units = abrupt rise in expired nitrogen conc. = closing volume
question4: How is dead space type (2) space measured?
contents4:
Respiratory dead space is the volume of inspired gas that does not take part in gas exchange. It is divided into anatomical and alveolar dead space.


Physiological dead space (Anatomical dead space + Alveolar dead space): 

  • Bohr’s method for calculating physiological dead space:
  • VD/VT = (PACO2 - PECO2) / PACO2


  • Inspired CO2 is ignored
  • PACO2 = measured arterial PCO2, assumed to be no difference
